Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Regulation of CpNifS/CpSufE1-Mediated Iron-Sulfur Cluster Synthesis in Plant Plastids. Implications for Sulfur and Iron Metabolism and Selenium Tolerance

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:

Photosynthesis, the production of sugars from water and carbon dioxide, takes place in plant chloroplasts and drives all life on our planet. The chloroplasts are also needed for the production of the oxygen that we breathe and, additionally, make nitrogen and sulfur compounds necessary for plant growth and a healthy plant-based diet. Iron deficiency limits plant growth because iron is available only at very low levels in soils and iron is essential for photosynthesis. Photosynthesis requires numerous proteins, many of which are dependent upon iron-sulfur clusters for proper protein function. This project aims to study how the machinery that assembles iron-sulfur clusters in chloroplasts is regulated. The integration of (1) sulfur and iron metabolism and their regulation and (2) iron-sulfur cluster assembly will get special attention in this project. The regulatory roles of plant-specific proteins that function in iron-sulfur cluster assembly will be delineated. This collaborative research additionally seeks to explore how selenium, which is similar to sulfur yet toxic, interferes with essential sulfur metabolism in chloroplasts. Moreover, the role of specific iron-sulfur cluster-related proteins in selenium metabolism will be analyzed. An interdisciplinary approach involving a combination of biochemistry, genetics and plant physiology in the model plant Arabidopsis will be employed. New analysis methods for the assembly of iron-sulfur clusters in vivo will be developed. These collaborative studies will provide much-needed insights into the mechanisms and regulation of assembly of the photosynthetic machinery in plants.

Broader impacts:

This research involves collaboration between Coastal Carolina University, a primarily undergraduate institution with 18% minority enrollment, and Colorado State University. The project will train several undergraduate students, a graduate student, and a post-doctoral fellow. Undergraduate students at CCU will be engaged and trained in cutting edge research methods. The project directly involves students in a larger undergraduate course in the excitement of hypothesis-driven research in a unique and innovative part of the project, which integrates classroom teaching and research, thereby increasing scientific understanding of a large group of students. Iron is limiting to crop growth in many environments; selenium contamination is increasingly problematic. Therefore, the results of the collaborative project will also have direct implications for agriculture, biomass production, the production of fortified foods, and the environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit
Iron (Fe) is the most abundant element in the universe and the 4th most abundant in the earth’s crust. Iron plays a very important role as part of cofactors in various enzymes and this element is essential to life. In plants, iron is of particular importance in photosynthesis, the process that drives all of life, and roughly 80% of the iron in green tissues is found in the sub-cellular organelle responsible for photosynthesis called the chloroplast.  

The most abundant type of iron cofactor is formed by the iron-sulfur clusters. Despite its abundance, iron is not readily available because much of it is bound in insoluble oxides. While iron is essential to life this element can also cause toxicity due to redox-activity of the free ions which leads to oxidative stress and cellular damage. Therefore, it is a challenge for living organisms to form iron cofactors such as iron-sulfur clusters: release of sulfur from cysteine and association with iron needs to be carefully coordinated. This project was aimed to study the regulation of iron-sulfur clusters in plant chloroplasts. We used a combined biochemical and physiological approach. For regulation we were especially interested in the cross-talk between sulfur and iron metabolism and responses to challenges such as iron limitation and oxidative stress. The project focused on four proteins of the system. The core of the iron-sulfur assembly system is the two-component cysteine desulfurase composed of CpNifS and SufE, which provides the sulfur for cluster formation. We also analyzed the function of IscA, a possible carrier required to bring clusters to target enzymes, and the enzyme APS, which functions in enzymatic sulfate reduction in plastids. APS is itself an iron-sulfur cluster protein. We developed a functional assay for the CpNifS/SufE complex. Surprisingly, abundance and activity of the CpNifS/SufE complex was not affected by iron supply but many (but not all) chloroplast iron-sulfur enzymes were affected. This means that activity of the cluster assembly system has to be controlled by interaction or activities of other enzymes. Biochemical assays suggest that APR might interact with SufE and thus regulate its activity. Interestingly, APR is itself dramatically affected by iron depletion, similar to IscA. Our findings suggest a model for the regulation of iron-sulfur cluster assembly, which we have started to test using selected Arabidopsis mutants and transgenics. Using APR loss-of function lines we found that one APR isoform is especially important not only for sulfur assimilation but also for tolerance to
the toxic element selenium, which in its chemical behavior is similar to
sulfur. IscA loss-of function lines showed iron-dependent growth phenotypes on basic (calcareous) soils. Some of the work of our mutants and transgenics is still ongoing with long-term further analysis via collaborations in the Pilon-lab group.

Eight peer-reviewed journal articles resulted from this project. Furthermore, the results of the project have been presented at a number of conferences including the international iron-sulfur cluster meetings. The project also established a firm collaboration between the laboratories of Dr Pilon at Colorado State University and Dr Van Hoewyk at Carolina Coastal University on one hand and the group of Dr Gaymard and Dr Ravet in Montpellier, France.
